email.subject: [PHP-GTK-DEV] gtk_menu_popup
email.body:
I've just spent about a week trying to make sense of this.
Andrei already did something to it so it will only accept 5 parameters (user_data \ doesn't seem to get accepted unless I'm doing some bad thing to it).
The first two parameters should always be null for a popup menu. They are there \ because they are used internally to associate a popup with a menubar or optionmenu \ (because there is NO SUCH THING AS A DROPDOWN GTKMENU).
The third parameter refers to another callback function which needs to return an \ array of co-ordinates (x, y). It can be null, and if so there is a default in place \ for it (the menu pops up at the pointer position).
The fourth parameter does nothing, even in the depths of GTK code, and really \ shouldn't be there at all as it refers to mouse-button options in a callback which \ could equally well be triggered by a key-press-event or enter-notify-event signal. \ Havoc informs me that it refers to the button-release-event button, but I'm still \ struggling to see its purpose.
The fifth parameter could permanently be $event->time(); as far as I can see ....
menu->popup(); would be a lot more straightforward to use if we could lose the first \ 2 parameters, set the callback position array to be automatically generated somehow \ from any input other than 'null', lose parameter 4, and maybe (I dunno) lose \ parameter 5 as well ...
Comments, anyone? Patches?

email.body:
Here's a couple questions, maybe someone can answer one (or both!) of these:
1] It seems that one has *no* control over scrollbars whatsoever -- it appears to be impossible to make a scrollbar scroll up or down without the user dragging on it.
Is there *any* way I can force a scrollbar to go to the bottom without the user having to click it?
Failing that, is there a way to make it so a GtkText's scrollbar will follow outputted data? My GtkText box is for data output only, so it never has keyboard focus -- I need it, so when text is inserted into it, it will automatically scroll to the bottom.
2] Currently, my application involves a GtkTable, 16x16, of 32x32 pixmaps. I will often be updating this entire screen, rather than just one or two pixmaps. During certain large updates -- most noticably, along the diagonal -- the entire pixmap area will appear to "flicker".
Is there anything like GtkText's freeze() and thaw() methods for pixmaps? Because if I could somehow make Gtk wait until I've made all my updates *then* display them, I believe the flicker would be avoided -- since I think it's trying to update *during* my while loop to place new tiles, I believe that's what's causing the flicker.
... If I can't do that, I'll probably end up writing it such that I combine all the tiles into one big pixmap before displaying them on the screen, which will be a bit of a pain but I believe that will avoid the flicker.
Anyway ... if anyone has insight, please let me know!
Steve

in the php-gtk docs it's clearly stated that php-gtk is NOT meant to be used in a webserver, so it's quite clear that one MUST have two php versions if one wants to use php for those different things.

I've just spent about a week trying to make sense of this.
Andrei already did something to it so it will only accept 5 parameters (user_data \ doesn't seem to get accepted unless I'm doing some bad thing to it).
The first two parameters should always be null for a popup menu. They are there \ because they are used internally to associate a popup with a menubar or optionmenu \ (because there is NO SUCH THING AS A DROPDOWN GTKMENU).
The third parameter refers to another callback function which needs to return an \ array of co-ordinates (x, y). It can be null, and if so there is a default in place \ for it (the menu pops up at the pointer position).
The fourth parameter does nothing, even in the depths of GTK code, and really \ shouldn't be there at all as it refers to mouse-button options in a callback which \ could equally well be triggered by a key-press-event or enter-notify-event signal. \ Havoc informs me that it refers to the button-release-event button, but I'm still \ struggling to see its purpose.
The fifth parameter could permanently be $event->time(); as far as I can see ....
menu->popup(); would be a lot more straightforward to use if we could lose the first \ 2 parameters, set the callback position array to be automatically generated somehow \ from any input other than 'null', lose parameter 4, and maybe (I dunno) lose \ parameter 5 as well ...
Comments, anyone? Patches?

email.subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] 0.5.0 testing
email.body:
Hi,
Andrei Zmievski wrote:
> I've uploaded php-gtk-0.5.0.tar.gz to the server. It's not publicly > released yet - I'd like you to download it and give it a once over > testing.
ok, this was really a superficial quicktest only. i've downloaded php 4.1.1, compiled it with --prefix=/usr/local/php-cgi/4.1.1 only. then got php-gtk 0.5.0 and configured like this:
./configure --prefix=/usr/local/php-gtk/0.5.0 --disable-libglade --with-php-config=/usr/local/php-cgi/4.1.1/bin/php-config
(have no libglade...)
make, make install ... without a hitch.
then i started the tutorial script from my hp - not a heavy one, only some buttons, a text field and a CList - worked without a problem.
then i started test/gtk.php - maybe there are some issues, i am not sure. here is what i saw:
- the second test, "buttons": if i click a button, another one disappears - i guess that is intended?
- 4. test, CList: wether or not you activate "reorderable", it is always reorderable. if i drag a clist item on my desktop (KDE), php-gtk says: "Gtk-CRITICAL **: file gtkselection.c: line 908 (gtk_selection_request): assertion `(data.format >= 8) && (data.format % 8 == 0)' failed." finally, the button "undo selection" does do anything.
- 6. test, CTree: again, the tree is always reorderble, and again the same error is caused if i drag something on the desktop. ah, now i see: if i deactivate "reorderable", i cannot no longer drag items, same for clist!
- 9. test, dragndrop: interesting - if here i drag the button on the desktop, no error is caused. err, in the second i wrote that sentence before, one of the books from test no. 6 that i dragged on the desktop flew over my screen... magic..
- 14 test, label: the very last sentence that reads "this one is underlines in quite a funky fashion" has some strange symbols (like russian letters) in front "quite"
- last test, tooltips: the second button has a long tooltip that is correctly wrapped, but not wrapped at all and therefore not completely visible beneath the button "tooltip inspector" if activated via the tooltip inspector.
thats all, sorry i have no time for more. if tomorrow i have time i install libglade and try php-gtk 0.5.0 with phpmole, that seems to be the most complex php-gtk app currently around.
nevertheless, my true respect for you, andrei!
-- Manuel Kiessling manuel@kiessling.net http://manuel.kiessling.net/
